title: Do I need to file bankruptcy, if I havent paid the creditors in over 3 years? I also had a home and did cash for keys.
question: I owe a lot of money to my credit cards and need to know if I still have to pay or file bankruptcy. I had a home with two loans. I havent paid anything and avoid all collectors. I am wondering if it will go away in 4 years, or am I suppose to file to make it stop? I live in CA and want to know how much I would have to re-pay.
answers: Call Steve Kremer a very experienced BK attorney for a free consultation. His number is 415- 292-7230

You've received two good answers. I'll add that whether it would be a good idea for you to file bankruptcy at this time depends on your entire financial situation. I recommend that you get a free consultation with a qualified Bay Area bankruptcy attorney to explore your situation.

On the credit card debt, the big issue is whether the statute of limitations really has run on the debt after 4 years (if you made any payments, promises to pay, and/or have been sued on these debts - the statute of limitations may not be up). I'm not a California lawyer so I can't say for sure, especially based on the limited information you have provided.

IF, the statute of limitations is up, you can write your unsecured creditors (such as credit cards) and inform them that you do not want to be contacted anymore on the phone. The Fair Debt Collections Act requires that they abide by this request.

As for the home, I'm assuming you are still making your payments on the house. If you are, then you are ok. If you are not, you may have problems.

Finally, if/until the statute of limitations is expired on the debts you are not paying, you are still subject to more severe collection actions. This varies by state, but often includes wage garnishments, cleaning out bank acccounts, and seizing non-exempt assets.

So, I think you should talk to a lawyer. Most will charge a minimal fee to discuss your options. Bankruptcy may or may not be necessary based on your circumstances.

Good luck!

The home loans might also be of concern. If the second was non purchase money (I.e. you took the loan out for some reason other than purchasing the property) then the holder of the 2nd can sue you. Check out link below. And speak to an attorney.

It would help to understand what you want to accomplish. By delaying filing bankruptcy, you are destroying your credit month after month & running the risk that at any moment before the statute of limitations expires, that a creditor will file suit against you.

I am posting a link to a couple of reports I have written to explain when you might want to file bankruptcy now vs filing later or not at all.

As to how much you might have to pay if you filed bankruptcy, it will really depend on what your budget shows you can afford to pay. For many people who are in financial distress, that amount is $0. Others pay some, still others pay 100%.

Hope this perspective helps!

The debts do not go away. Once the statute of limitations runs, the collectors can no longer sue (though in some states you have to raise the statute of limitations as a defense or waive it). If you start paying again, you will restart the statute of limitations. If the debts are high enough, talk to a local bankruptcy attorney about whether this option is right for you.
